title: $15/hour
text: How do you think the new minimum wage law will affect Seattle? Will it be for the better or for the worse? Why?

comments.text: Not sure I believe any of this...
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: the sky is blue
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: the minimum wage should $25 per hour
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: foo
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Businesses, small or large, shouldn't be able to pay workers anything below a livable wage. Why should we subsidize businesses that depend on inadequate wages? If a business's product is good, then this shouldn't be a challenge.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Poop.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Higher wages makes it super hard for small businesses to survive.  In effect, mom and pop coffee shops with disappear.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Something needs to be done to address income inequality and this is a good if imperfect start
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Minimum wage will not just lead to robots. Minimum wage will lead to unionized robots. And that's a good thing.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: It's possible benefits may be cut in exchange for higher wages, along with other benefits. Worth it?
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Edward Tufte talks about a "supergraphic". It's a chart or display that is so effective it causes people to ignore the speaker, but yet they totally get it. This is one of those.

comments.text: It’s called a ‘living wage’ for a reason - there shouldn’t be a debate about the ethics of the law. Anyone who has done the math knows that it’s impossible to pay rent and bills on the present minimum wage.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Given inflation, unless workers fight they are continually being pushed down. I think we’ll need to revisit these laws again and again to make sure the economy is working for poor families.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I think it is unlikely that companies will raise prices, as they still have to remain competitive in the market. I think it is more likely that companies will have less profits and I’m ok with that.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: Paying $15/hour to tens of millions of workers around the country will increase the amount they and their families can spend on goods and services, which would provide a huge boost to the economy.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: During the campaign, I found out that 75% of minimum-wage workers are 20 or older. I think it’s the right thing to do to bring higher incomes to this group of people.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I think there are better ways to implement this. For instance, what about subsidies
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I don't think it's a bad thing but for smaller businesses, only the super strong will survive. It will mean that only owners who are willing and able to work every day at their own businesses to reduce labor costs will survive.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: This will lead to robots.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: While the arguments for the raise in the minimum wage law have been trumpeted as being “anti corporate greed”, those larger companies are, ironically, the most able to pay for the increase in wages. This will hurt small businesses the most, and I don’t think the law’s provisions do enough to accommodate this.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: There seems to be a fallacy that instead of lining our richie-rich pockets, business owners will simply break off a little more for their employees. I’m an owner of a small business, and I barely get paid $15 an hour.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: At the very least, customers across the board are going to have to pay more to accommodate the new wage. Some people will be okay with that but I worry that customers will start spending less and going out less as they adjust to higher prices.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: This is a game changer. The myriad of unintended consequences it too complex to really understand; even for restaurant veterans.
comments.author: Anonymous

comments.text: I imagine new businesses opening will run counter operations where guests grab their own silverware and bus their own tables.
comments.author: Anonymous
